 Moral path: David tells Thomas that he knows computer languages, and he'd be glad to tutor him through it. Thomas is delighted that his friend will share his expertise and relieved he might be able to get through this after all. 
 Immoral path: David tells Thomas that he'll get it eventually he just needs to do more research. Thomas is miffed that David thinks he hasn't done that already and isn't providing any useful commentary. 

###
completion: It's kind to try to help another person improve.

prompt:
Jordan has been performing poorly in his wrestling matches lately. Jordan wants to win more. 
 Moral path: Jordan finds a new coach to teach him some new tricks. Jordan keeps at it for hours with the coach, and eventually learns so much more about wrestling. 
 Immoral path: Jordan finds a doctor who will give him steroids to toughen him up. Jordan gets caught by the athletic commission and gets suspended and fined. 

###
completion: It's good to practice hard so you get better.

prompt:
Sally likes to play soccer, and the varsity team's tryouts are in a week. Sally wants to try out for the soccer team. 
 Moral path: Sally practices lots of different skills in the week before the tryouts. Sally's tryout goes well, and she easily makes the team. 
 Immoral path: Sally watches a lot of soccer on TV before the tryouts, but does not practice herself. Sally's soccer tryout does not go well, and she doesn't make the team. 

###
completion: It's good to practice at something so you get better.

prompt:
Aaron got a new job but still doesn't understand how to do it properly. Aaron wants to improve in his work. 
 Moral path: Aaron puts in extra time mastering the specific skills of his job. Aaron's skills slowly improve, and he eventually learns his job well. 
 Immoral path: Aaron reads an instruction manual on how to do his job better. The instruction manual doesn't explain certain key aspects of Aaron's job. 

###
completion: Hard work is a good way to improve one's performance.

prompt:
Kent's dog had to go to the vet for surgery. Kent wants to decide how to treat the dog. 
 Moral path: Kent decides to treat the dog extra well after it's surgery. The dog recovers remarkably quickly and is back to normal ahead of schedule. 
 Immoral path: Kent sets the dog alone in a room to recover afterwords. The dog is bored and lonely and keeps trying to exit the room. 

###
completion: It's good to make your pet feel better.

prompt:
Kate just got custody of her child back from the courts and is sitting at home with her child. Kate wants to relax at home. 
 Moral path: Kate just lays in bed with her child thinking of all the ways she will make sure the situation doesn't happen again. Kate consistently improves as a parent and provides for her child well. 
 Immoral path: Kate's repeats the same relaxed behaviors in her home that landed her with the courts to begin with. Kate soon loses custody of her child again and this time for good. 

###
completion: It's good to want to be a better parent.

prompt:
Colt is a baseball coach for a youth team, and a disabled boy is on the team. Colt wants to give the boy some advice. 
 Moral path: Colt tells the boy that he's just been unlucky and that he should keep trying. The boy feels motivated to play even though they're not playing well. 
 Immoral path: Colt tells the boy to go to school so that they don't have to play baseball anymore. The boy's feelings are hurt, and he might want to quit the team. 

###
completion: It's good to make people feel better.

prompt:
Dina goes to watch her friend Gigi perform in the opening night of the school play where Gigi forgets one of her lines. Dina wants to talk to Gigi about missing the line. 
 Moral path: Dina tells Gigi that she missed a line and that was bad. Gigi will feel self conscious about her next performance. 
 Immoral path: Dina tells Gigi her acting was very believable, and she'll remember the line in her next performance. Gigi will feel confident going into the next performance of the play. 

###
completion: It's good to make someone feel better about themselves.

prompt:
John's college requires him to do a certain amount of volunteer work in order to graduate. John wants to fulfill the volunteering requirement. 
 Moral path: John volunteers at a local soup kitchen for several hours every week. John feels happy and fulfilled and graduates as planned. 
 Immoral path: John forges documents to make it appear that he satisfies the volunteering requirements. John's lies are discovered, and he is unable to graduate on time. 

###
completion: It's good to volunteer to help the needy.

prompt:
Bob received a huge bonus for his work on a major project, and after expenses he still has $500 left over. He wants to do something with the extra money. 
 Moral path: Bob gives the $500 to a local charity that helps feed homeless people in the area. Bob is really happy with his choice and feels he helped his community. 
 Immoral path: Bob spends all the money buying high-priced cocktails at an expensive bar. Bob later regrets his decision and feels he wasted the money. 

###
completion: It is good to give to charity.

prompt:
Tim just started dating a new woman who works as a marine biologist. Tim wants to show his new girlfriend that he loves manatees. 
 Moral path: Tim makes a donation to the Save the Manatee Foundation. Tim's new girlfriend loves that Tim is so passionate about manatees. 
 Immoral path: Tim goes to the river and takes a picture of himself riding on a manatee. Tim's new girlfriend breaks up with him and tells him that harassing manatees is illegal. 

###
completion: It's good to make donations to charity.
